metadata.description: Normalized schema for real-world data analytics job postings dataset
metadata.source: Luke Barousse Data Jobs Dataset from HuggingFace
metadata.normalization_approach: Dimensional modeling with fact table (jobs) and dimension tables (companies, locations, platforms, skills)

tables.name: companies
tables.description: Contains information about companies that post job listings
tables.creation_query:
CREATE TABLE companies AS
SELECT DISTINCT 
    ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY company_name) as company_id,
    company_name
FROM raw_jobs_data 
WHERE company_name IS NOT NULL
ORDER BY company_name;

columns.name: company_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each company

columns.name: company_name
columns.description: Name of the company posting the job

tables.name: job_skills
tables.description: Junction table linking jobs to their required skills (many-to-many relationship)
tables.creation_query:
CREATE TABLE job_skills AS
SELECT DISTINCT
    j.job_id,
    s.skill_id
FROM jobs j
CROSS JOIN skills s
WHERE 
    -- Pattern matching job descriptions/titles for skill requirements
    LOWER(j.job_title) LIKE '%' || LOWER(s.skill_name) || '%'
    OR LOWER(j.job_title_short) LIKE '%' || LOWER(s.skill_name) || '%'
    -- Additional skill detection logic would be applied here
ORDER BY j.job_id, s.skill_id;

columns.name: job_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each job posting

columns.name: skill_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each skill

tables.name: jobs
tables.description: Main table containing all job postings with details like title, salary, and requirements
tables.creation_query:
CREATE TABLE jobs AS
SELECT 
    j.job_id,
    c.company_id,
    l.location_id, 
    p.platform_id,
    j.job_title_short,
    j.job_title,
    j.job_schedule_type,
    j.job_work_from_home,
    j.job_posted_date,
    j.job_no_degree_mention,
    j.job_health_insurance,
    j.salary_rate,
    j.salary_year_avg,
    j.salary_hour_avg
FROM raw_jobs_data j
LEFT JOIN companies c ON j.company_name = c.company_name
LEFT JOIN locations l ON j.job_location = l.job_location AND j.job_country = l.job_country  
LEFT JOIN platforms p ON j.job_via = p.platform_name;

columns.name: job_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each job posting

columns.name: company_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each company

columns.name: location_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each location

columns.name: platform_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each job posting platform

columns.name: job_title_short
columns.description: Standardized job title category (e.g., "Data Scientist", "Data Engineer")

columns.name: job_title
columns.description: Full job title as posted by the company

columns.name: job_schedule_type
columns.description: Employment type (full-time, part-time, contract, etc.)

columns.name: job_work_from_home
columns.description: Boolean indicating if remote work is available

columns.name: job_posted_date
columns.description: Date and time when the job was posted

columns.name: job_no_degree_mention
columns.description: Boolean indicating if the job posting mentions no degree requirement

columns.name: job_health_insurance
columns.description: Boolean indicating if health insurance is mentioned as a benefit

columns.name: salary_rate
columns.description: Rate type for salary (yearly, hourly, etc.)

columns.name: salary_year_avg
columns.description: Average yearly salary in USD

columns.name: salary_hour_avg
columns.description: Average hourly salary in USD

sample_data.job_title: Senior Clinical Data Engineer / Principal Clinical Data Engineer ...

tables.name: locations
tables.description: Geographic information for job locations including city and country
tables.creation_query:
CREATE TABLE locations AS
SELECT DISTINCT
    ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY job_location, job_country) as location_id,
    job_location,
    job_country
FROM raw_jobs_data
WHERE job_location IS NOT NULL
ORDER BY job_country, job_location;

columns.name: location_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each location

columns.name: job_location
columns.description: City or geographic area where the job is located

columns.name: job_country
columns.description: Country where the job is located

tables.name: platforms
tables.description: Job posting platforms (LinkedIn, Indeed, etc.) where jobs are advertised
tables.creation_query:
CREATE TABLE platforms AS
SELECT DISTINCT
    ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY job_via) as platform_id,
    job_via as platform_name
FROM raw_jobs_data
WHERE job_via IS NOT NULL
ORDER BY job_via;

columns.name: platform_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each job posting platform

columns.name: platform_name
columns.description: Name of the platform (e.g., "via LinkedIn", "via Indeed")

tables.name: skills
tables.description: Available skills that can be required for jobs, categorized by type
tables.creation_query:
CREATE TABLE skills AS
SELECT skill_id, skill_name, skill_category
FROM (VALUES 
    (1, 'Python', 'programming'),
    (2, 'SQL', 'programming'), 
    (3, 'R', 'programming'),
    (4, 'Excel', 'analyst_tools'),
    (5, 'Tableau', 'analyst_tools'),
    (6, 'Power BI', 'analyst_tools'),
    (7, 'AWS', 'cloud'),
    (8, 'Azure', 'cloud'),
    (9, 'GCP', 'cloud'),
    (10, 'Spark', 'big_data'),
    (11, 'Hadoop', 'big_data'),
    (12, 'Docker', 'devops'),
    (13, 'Kubernetes', 'devops'),
    (14, 'Git', 'devops'),
    (15, 'Machine Learning', 'analytics')
) AS t(skill_id, skill_name, skill_category);

columns.name: skill_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each skill

columns.name: skill_name
columns.description: Name of the skill (e.g., "Python", "SQL", "Excel")

columns.name: skill_category
columns.description: Category of the skill (programming, analyst_tools, cloud, etc.)

relationships.description: One company can have many job postings
One location can have many job postings
One platform can have many job postings
Jobs can require multiple skills, and skills can be required by multiple jobs

schema_notes: Database follows normalized design principles with dimensional modeling approach
All dimension tables (companies, locations, platforms, skills) were extracted from the original dataset
The jobs table serves as the central fact table with foreign key references
Foreign key relationships ensure data integrity and enable efficient JOINs
Junction table (job_skills) implements many-to-many relationship between jobs and skills
Creation queries show the normalization process from raw data to structured schema
Salary information is in USD where available
Date format follows ISO 8601 standard (YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS)
Schema is optimized for educational SQL exercises and real-world analysis
